control chemical hazards and chemical usages at PORTS.  Engineering is responsible for the
generation, application, and overall management of process safety information as it applies to
chemical safety, structures, systems, and components.  

Process safety information is reviewed and approved as identified in the implementation
procedures.  These reviews and approvals vary in accordance with the application of graded risk.  

An Engineering Service Order [ESO] is required for modifications to existing systems.  The ESO
process provides a mechanism that identifies new or revised usages of chemicals, chemical
processes, and/or associated logistics that require engineering involvement.  The engineering
management system utilizes independent and multi-discipline reviews and approvals for ESO-
related activities.  

Engineering and quality records are processed and maintained in accordance with Quality
Assurance, Records Management, and Document Control program requirements as discussed in
the Recordkeeping Section of this RMP.

Periodic programmatic reports, field validation requirements, configuration management reviews
and assessment, and independent evaluation processes are used as part of the engineering
management system for process safety information.

Process Hazard Analyses and Methodology Used

 Safety Analysis Report - The SAR describes the technical basis program requirements for
chemical safety; the integration of chemical safety with the uranium enrichment operations; and
describes the management systems used for chemical safety.  The SAR is subject to upgrades and
revisions as required to ensure continued safe operations including revisions related to chemical
process safety.

Process Hazard Analysis - Chemicals are used at PORTS that are managed in accordance with
29 CFR 1910.119 PSM requirements.  The PSM program manages these hazardous chemicals in
a manner that prevents impact to workers and the public.  The hazard analyses

are used to
identify and manage chemical risks and impacts to plant systems or operations, workers and to
the public.  Specific job-related risks, the technical controls and administrative controls used for
risk management are addressed in the specific PHAs.  

The OSHA PHAs used the Failure Mode and Effects methodology to identify the potential
hazards and risks.  The PHAs were prepared by PORTS safety analysis personnel or the use of
consultants having related professional credentials.  The PHAs were reviewed, revised and
upgraded as controlled documents in October, 1998.
 
Industrial Hygiene and Safety Program Hazard Analysis - Commercial chemicals, such as
HF and chlorine, have varying toxicity and hazardous ranges and categories of consequences. 
Industrial hygiene and safety program applications provides accepted industrial standards and
regulatory requirements for protection from hazardous chemicals during daily operations and
emergency responses.  

Corrective Actions Management System 

Plant problems, issues, and concerns are addressed in accord with the USEC Quality Assurance
Plan [QAP].  A corrective action management system, based upon the ASME NQA-1
requirements for Corrective Action, ensures that significant conditions adverse to quality are
mitigated, the cause of the condition is determined, corrective action is taken to preclude
recurrence, and ensures that followup actions are taken to verify implementation of the corrective
actions.  These actions are documented and reported to appropriate levels of management in
accordance with the implementing procedures.

Procedures Management System

USEC is required to describe its management controls and oversight program governing
activities directly relevant to nuclear safety safeguards and security in accordance with 10 CFR
76.35(a)(7).  Controlled written procedures are utilized to conduct operations for the protection
of the general public, plant employees, and the environment.  A balanced combinatio

n of written
guidance, craftsman skills, and work site supervision are utilized to achieve the protection of the
public, plant employees, and the environment.

Procedures are developed or modified through a formal process incorporating change controls. 
The change controls establish a protocol to ensure technical, operations, maintenance, and
administrative procedures are properly developed, received, approved, revised and controlled. 
The procedures are periodically reviewed in accordance with the procedure program
requirements associated with the specific function.

Training Program 

The USEC training program, established in accordance with 10 CFR 76.35(a), requires USEC to
establish, implement and maintain a training program for individuals relied upon to operate,
maintain or modify the GDPs in a safe manner.  The training program for such individuals shall
be based upon a systems approach to training.  The USEC Training Program organization and
administration is a full-time group that consists of a centralized staff reporting directly to the
Training Manager.  

Equipment Inspection and Test Status 
 
USEC Maintenance and Work Control organizations provide for the safe, reliable, and cost-
effective maintenance of the plant.  Routine maintenance work is identified, prioritized, planned,
scheduled, executed, and closed-out in accordance with the work control program requirements. 
The maintenance and surveillance program consists of a mix of preventative maintenance,
corrective maintenance, and calibration requirements.  Maintenance for the plant is performed in
accordance with the Quality Assurance, Engineering and Configuration Management program
requirements.

Post Maintenance Testing

Post Maintenance Testing [PMT] requirements are developed by engineering for commonly
required repairs to verify the adequacy of those repairs.  Special PMT requirements may be
requested on a case-by-case basis.  PMT performance and acceptance is documented in the work
package.

The alternate release scenario for fluorine involves a complete break in the interconnecting

ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM AND CHEMICAL SPECIFIC
PREVENTION STEPS

USEC has addressed release potentials and risks in safety analysis documents and by the use of
management systems.  Details of these mitigative actions to ensure safe operating conditions can
be found in Application For United States Nuclear Regulatory Commission Certification
Portsmouth Gaseous Diffusion Plant Safety Analysis Report and in 29 CFR 1910.119 PHAs for
the X-342 Fluorine Generation Complex and the X-611E Water Treatment Facility.

These site-level systems apply uniformly for the management of structures, systems, programs,
and components that pertain to a RMP covered process and related activities.

Five-Year Accident History
 
PORTS five year history exhibits a chemical release performance of no significant or threshold
quantity release of chlorine, fluorine, or HF.  Minor releases can occur during routine operations
and maintenance activities, but have not resulted in significant personnel exposure or
environmental impacts.

As-Found Conditions - Any as-found condition that does not agree with the description in the
SAR [including programs, plans, policies, and operations] must be approved in accordance with
the above provisions or corrected to match the SAR.  

Program Document Control - Proposed changes to the Emergency Plan [EP], QAP, or other

occur without NRC approval if changes would decrease the effectiveness.   These changes shall

Physical Plant Changes and Configuration - The control of changes to the physical plant and
control of the physical plant configuration are managed by the Design Authority [Engineering].

The documents and analysis reports for changes are managed as described in the Recordkeeping
and Controlled Document programs described elsewhere.

PRE-STARTUP REVIEW HISTORY

USEC has a management system to address plant changes and the requirements to review and
approve activities prior to restart or return to operational service.  These reviews can be very
simple to extensive efforts dependent upon the associated risk and sensitivity of the particular
operation.  

Programmatic reviews that would involve chemical safety issues include:

     1.   Facility modifications, additions, or changes having a 10 CFR 76.68 review
          performed.  
  
     2.   Modification to the facility procedures, personnel training, testing programs, or
          regulatory documents.

     3.   Modifications being evaluated and documented to minimize worker exposure in

Work Control

The Work Control Organization is responsible for coordinating, planning and scheduling of
maintenance work activities; providing overall scheduling of capital projects; and implementing
controls to provide a record of work accomplished.

Authorization for release of equipment or systems for maintenance is granted by designated
organizational managers and is documented in the work package.  Operational authorization is
based upon verification that the equipment or system may be taken out of service.  The work
package identifies other needed work permits and the affected equipment or system being
isolated to provide protection for plant personnel and equipment.  When the equipment is
returned to service, Operations verifies and documents satisfactory completion of the post-
maintenance testing, and places the equipment in operation.

For detailed history of specific system equipment and test / inspection records, the history file is
maintained by the Work Control and Records Management programs. 

Management of Change and History of Change

USEC may make changes to the plant or plant operations from that described in the SAR
provided the following provisions of 10 CFR 76.68(a) are satisfied:

1.   Conduct a written safety analysis that demonstrates that the change would not result in
     undue risk to public health and safety, the common defense and security, or to the
     environment.

 2.  The changes must be authorized by responsible management and approved by the Plant
     Operations Review Committee [PORC].

3.   The changes may not decrease effectiveness of the plant's safety, safeguards, and security
     programs.

4.   The changes may not involve a change to any condition to the certification of compliance.

5.   The changes may not involve a change to any condition to the approved compliance plan.

6.   The changes may not involve an unreviewed safety question.

During the process of transition from a Department of Energy [DOE]-regulated environment to
that of a commercial private industry, a detailed Compliance Plan was prepared by the DOE to
ensure upgrades were implemented where needed to comply with commercial and NRC
requirements.  This Compliance Plan represented any planned changes needed to improve site
safety that included chemical safety related activities.  The Compliance Plan is comprehensive
and includes the use of hazardous or toxic chemicals by near-by third parties which may impact
USEC operations and personnel.  

Additionally, Memorandums of Understanding were implemented between the OSHA, the NRC,
and the EPA to share and reinforce regulatory compliance and safety performance.  

During this transitional period, plant operations and activities were reviewed and upgraded to
ensure a safe operation.  Reviews of chemical safety-related areas included improved and
upgraded safety analysis documentation, facility and equipment descriptions, quantitative hazard
and accident analyses, classifications of safety structures, systems, and components and
programmatic controls.  Additional improvements addressed included hazardous material
protection [chemical safety], initial testing, in-service surveillance and maintenance testing;
operational safety; procedures and training, quality assurance, emergency preparedness program
management organization, and institutional safety provisions.  Each of these functional areas
have appropriate applications to the 40 CFR 68 RMP.
 
USEC MANAGEMENT SYSTEMS

USEC is required to describe its management controls and oversight program governing
activities directly relevant to nuclear safety safeguards, and security in accordance with 10 CFR
76.35(a)(7).  USEC has functional, administrative, and technical management systems to
implement RMP requirements.  These plant systems and programs, based upon 10 CFR 76
requirements, are applicable to the RMP covered processes as well as the g

eneral operation of the
plant.  These management systems are implemented by formal procedures and program policies. 
The following is a brief description and basis for the applicable management systems used for
chemical risk management.
 
 Management and Organization

USEC is committed to conducting operations in a manner that protects the health and safety of
workers and the public, protects the environment, and provides for the common defense and
security.  To meet these commitments, as well as others required for the operation of the uranium
enrichment enterprise, USEC has issued an operations policy manual which contains statements
of policy and procedures for day-to-day business operations and provides direction to USEC
employees.  USEC policy states, in part:

      USEC is ultimately responsible for, and is committed to safe operations,
     maintenance, modification, design, fabrication, and testing of the Portsmouth
     Gaseous Diffusion Plant [GDP], and is committed to conducting operations in a
     manner that protects the health and safety of workers and the public, protects the
     environment and provides for the common defense and security.  USEC has
     provided the management structure to ensure that the safety/safeguards policy is
     effectively implemented.

The management system includes the organizations and structure, the manager's title, the
managers' roles and responsibilities, and establishes accountabilities for their functional
assignments.  

Fundamentally, the line organizations are responsible for the safe operation of the GDP. 
Programs and staff organizations are established for Safety, Safeguards, and Quality and
Environmental, Safety, and Health [ES&H], with sufficient resources to support the line
organizations in safe operation of the GDP.
 
Safety Information Review

Safety information policy and procedures are established formal documents that define safe
operating parameters for plant operations.  The engineering functi

s regarding predictive and preventative maintenance; nuclear
safety; and the configuration management program.

The Engineering Manager is supported by the ES&H manager.   Job specific overview is the
responsibility of the Site Technical Representative assigned to the contractor and includes tasks
associated with or near hazardous chemicals or potential energy sources.  ES&H assists in areas
concerning site safety requirements and chemical usage.  Field activities are subject to periodic
visits by ES&H personnel.

Contractor personnel are trained to site requirements appropriate to their assigned tasks. Unless
otherwise indicated by contract, contractors are responsible to use and follow site procedures and
safety requirements.

EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM

USEC has established and prepared an EP to ensure that plant personnel are adequately prepared
for accidents and effective response actions are taken to mitigate the consequences of such
accidents and emergencies, and to protect the health and safety of the public and the workers at
the plant.  The emergency planning requirements set forth in 10 CFR 70 for other nuclear fuel
cycle facilities are appropriate for the GDPs and that the requirements in 10 CFR 76.91 are based
upon the emergency planning provisions in 10 CFR 70.  Accordingly, the format of the EP is
generally based upon NRC Regulatory Guide 3.67, Standard Format and Content for Emergency
Plans for Fuel Cycle and Materials Facilities.  
 
The EP provides an overall description of the site-wide emergency preparedness program, which
is based, on a large measure on the emergency preparedness policies, procedures, and practices
that have been successfully used at PORTS for over 40 years.  This program has been established
to manage and respond in a consistent and integrated fashion to accidents or other emergency
situations that may occur at the site.

The structure of this program is intended to ensure that the consequences of emergencies are
promptly mitig

s the management system an approach to address the
periodic upgrade requirement.  Regulatory upgrades may result from the following:

Regulatory changes - Regulatory actions resulting in a system or process scope change will be
addressed by the Change Control process.

New or modified processes - New or modified processes utilizing threshold quantities of
regulated chemicals will be addressed by the Change Control system and plant management
systems previously discussed in this RMP.  

Program Criteria Change/Revision -  Program criteria that result in a process or system change

RECORDKEEPING

The Records Management and Document Control programs are established to ensure records and
documents required by the QAP are appropriately designed to meet the specific recordkeeping
and document control requirements set forth in 10 CFR 76.

These systems provide administrative controls that establish standard methods and requirements
for collection, maintenance, distributing, and disposing records.  

Records Management Program

The Records Management program provides direction for the handling, transmittal, storage, and
retrieval of records.  Record media may include microfilm, electronic [magnetic or optical], or
hard copy.  Records are categorized and handled in accordance with their relative importance to
safety and storage needs.  Specific records are maintained for a period of time specified by
applicable NRC, Federal, or State requirements.  

Document Control Program

The Document Control program provides direction for the handling, distribution, and transmittal
of documents important to nuclear safety, safeguards, and security that specify quality
requirements or prescribe activities affecting quality, such as procedures, drawings, and
calculations.  

For documents and changes to documents dictated by the QAP, requirements are established for
approval and

release of those documents for distribution.  Certain critical documents requiring
review and approval by the PORC are identified in the Technical Safety Requirements [TSR] for
the PORC.  

Requirements for the review and approval of procedures are identified in the TSR for procedures
and in the formal procedures program.
 
AVAILABILITY OF INFORMATION TO THE PUBLIC

Controlled copies of the RMP will be provided in accordance with the EPA instructions and
guidance prescribed in 40 CFR 68.  Fulfillment of the RMP requirements will not involve 
classified data information or other intelligence that might be of national or company security. 
USEC does reserve the rights and provisions to address exceptions to this issue with the EPA and
other agencies as may be required.

AUDITS BY REGULATORY AGENCIES    

Regulatory agency audits will be addressed by the management systems described herein and in
the implementing procedures as well as the requirements and guiding criteria of the regulating
agency.  Audit corrective actions or issues generated by regulatory agency reviews will be
managed and processed as applicable within the framework of these same systems to ensure
management responsiveness.

COMPLIANCE AUDITS
 
The QAP includes an audit system which was established for Quality and Augmented Quality 
items and other activities and services within the scope of the QA

P.  The audit systems is in
accordance with Basic Requirement 18 and Supplement 18S-1 of NQA-1 (1989).  This system
establishes planned and periodic audits to verify the compliance and effectiveness of the QAP in
meeting quality requirements.

Independent internal audits of selected aspects of operational activities are performed with a
frequency commensurate with their safety significance and in a manner as to assure that audits of
activities within the scope of the QAP are completed within the specified time periods.  Audit
reports are managed as described in the Recordkeeping and Document Control program
descriptions found in other RMP sections.

Corrective actions and issues resulting from audits, investigations, and regulatory sources are
addressed by the Corrective Action management system discussed in this document.  These
audits and any corrective actions are processed by existing plant programs that include RMP
elements and requirements.
 
INCIDENT INVESTIGATIONS
 
USEC conducts incident and event investigations to protect employees, public health and safety,
the environment, and national security interests.  Incident investigations are conducted in
accordance with formal procedures.  If a large scale event were to occur, a special investigation
team may be appointed to investigate the incident.

Appropriate notification of an incident is by the specific program management and regulatory
requirements.  Notification is performed in accordance with formal procedures.

As part of this program, abnormal events are identified, reported, and investigated.  This includes
identification, categorization of the event and analysis to determine the root cause and its effect. 
The corrective actions developed as a result of the investigation are entered into a commitment
management database, which is a dedicated database used to track and trend corrective actions
and plant commitments.  This database also facilitates management's review of the corrective
actions and pla

nt commitment.

EMPLOYEE PARTICIPATION PLAN REVIEW AND REVISION
 
USEC manages operational safety with an Employee Participation Plan that involves personnel
on plant-site.  The Employee Participation Plan expresses expectations of the plant population
support and participation, and the individual's roles and responsibilities.  The Plan involves
personnel represented by organized labor, salary employees, and subcontractors.

The Employee Participation Plan, initially created with the Union Local Safety and Health
Representatives in 1994, is based upon the 29 CFR 1910.119 elements and supported by plant
policies and procedures.  The Employee Participation Plan is applied by formal plant
implementation procedures, e.g., reporting unsafe activities, emergency response expectations,
and configuration management controls.  

HOT WORK PERMIT REVIEW/REVISION

limit danger to life or property from fires.  The fire protection programs draw heavily on NFPA
codes and standards to provide an acceptable level of fire safety.  Part of the program elements
used is the hot work permit system.  The hot work permit in place is to ensure cutting,
welding, and other hot work conducted in areas not designated or approved for such processes
will be done in a manner that is consistent with industry fire preventative practices.

RISK MANAGEMENT PLAN EXECUTIVE SUMMARY
PORTSMOUTH GASEOUS DIFFUSION PLANT

INTRODUCTION

The United States Enrichment Company [USEC] has prepared a Risk Management Plan [RMP]
for the Portsmouth Gaseous Diffusion Plant [PORTS] in accordance with the requirements set
forth in Environmental Protection Agency [EPA] regulations 40 CFR Part 68 Accidental
Release Prevention Requirements: Risk Management Programs Under Clean Air Act Section
112(r)(7) Subpart G - Risk Management Plan. 

The Clean Air Act Section 112(r) consists of two components for risk management of hazardous
and toxic materials and related process systems - the Occupational Safety and Health
Administration's [OSHA] 29 CFR 1910.119 Process Safety Management [PSM] Standard and
40 CFR 68.  The PORTS plant is subject to both PSM and RMP chemical safety management
responsibilities.  

The gaseous diffusion process to enrich uranium requires certain hazardous chemicals that are
managed to an acceptable risk.  USEC has the management systems, risk control programs, and
policy and practices to effectively address operational chemical risks.  These operational risks are
managed from an accidental release prevention emphasis.  The USEC chemical risk management
programs and systems are based upon nearly fifty years safe operating experience and the
application of 10 CFR 76 requirements for a nuclear fuel cycle facility.  The Nuclear Regulatory
Commission [NRC] approved Certification, required for operation, includes chemical safety as
an integral program along with an on-going commitment to manage hazardous chemicals.  

The Certification Application includes detailed management systems descriptions that are
effectively implemented for chemical safety operations, concerns, and issues.  The management
systems ensure that chemical risks are properly identified and the necessary management rigor is
implemented to mitigate chemical operating risks and consequences.

The technical basis of chemical safety is the Safet

y Analysis Report [SAR].  The SAR describes
the uranium enrichment operations and the management systems and programs used for
operating the plant.  Chemical risks to the workers, the public and the environment are addressed
by safety analyses, process hazard analyses [PHA], commercial safety and health guidance, and
an emergency preparedness program.  

In addition to the NRC Certification process, PORTS is also covered by and in compliance with
the OSHA PSM and the Emergency Planning and Community Right-To-Know Act [EPCRA]
Section 302.  PORTS has also submitted an application for a Title V permit to the state of Ohio
in accordance with the applicable state regulations, but the permit has not yet been issued. 

PORTS has three toxic chemicals in threshold quantities stipulated in 40 CFR 68, Appendix A:
chlorine, fluorine and anhydrous hydrogen fluoride [HF].  These three chemicals are used in two
separate processes.  PORTS does not have any flammable chemicals subject to the RMP
regulations.

Process One - Chlorine

PORTS has its own water treatment plant that provides water for process cooling and sanitary
purposes.  The X-611 Water Treatment facilities, capable of treating over 20 million gallons of
water per day, produces up to 6 million gallons per day using a chlorine treatment process.  The
sanitary water treatment process is similar to other water treatment plants throughout the United
States that use chlorine to disinfect the water for sanitary purposes.

The chlorine, provided in 2,000 pound cylinders, has a maximum administrative limit of three
filled chlorine cylinders at any one time.  This quantity is in excess of the threshold quantities
listed in 40 CFR 68.  A typical working inventory is two cylinders attached to the system
manifold.  The third container, if present, would be in an unconnected storage position adjacent
to the in-use cylinders.  All three container positions are inside a building with a vehicle door to
accommodate deliveries.

The po

stulated worst case release scenario is based on a vehicle accident inside the chlorine
building that ruptures both the system manifold and the staged cylinder, causing the maximum
inventory to be released within the building in ten minutes.  Holdup within the building reduces
the release rate to the air by a factor of 0.55, as per the EPA's Offsite Consequence Analysis
[OCA] Guidelines.  The distance to the endpoint is taken from the applicable OCA table.

The alternate chlorine release scenario is based on a failure of the connector (a pigtail) between
the system manifold and a cylinder that causes both connected cylinders to be released into the
building at the calculated maximum flow rate through the manifold.  This flow rate was
calculated using a computer program called PIPELEAK and is part of the NRC-approved SAR. 
Again, holdup within the building reduces the release rate to the air by a factor of 0.55 and the
distance to the endpoint is taken from the applicable OCA table.  The chlorine system has both
manual and automatic shutoff systems that would limit an actual release, but no credit was taken
for these systems in this analysis.

Process Two - Fluorine and Hydrogen Fluoride

The X-342 fluorine generation complex produces fluorine from HF.  The HF is received in 850
pound cylinders, with up to two cylinders connected to the fluorine generation system inside a
heated cabinet within the X-342 building.  Additional cylinders are staged in a separate room. 
The HF is electrolytically disassociated into hydrogen, which is discharged to the atmosphere,
and fluorine, which is stored in a set of tanks enclosed in a third room.  The fluorine is used as
needed in the maintenance of the uranium enrichment equipment.  

The X-342 fluorine complex has the potential to release up to 1,290 pounds of fluorine or 6,800
pounds of HF.  The HF has an administrative limit of eight filled cylinders (nominally 850
pounds of HF per container) staged for use (unconnected but a
